items.synopsis: Israel has drafted a record 300,000 reservists in its response to a multi-front Hamas attack from Gaza and is "going on the offensive," its chief military spokesperson says.

title.children: Senior Hamas official says only a 'handful' of commanders knew of weekend attack on Israel

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli military has suggested that Palestinians fleeing its air strikes in the Gaza Strip head to Egypt, which also borders the blockaded enclave. "I am aware that the Rafah crossing (on the Gaza-Egypt border) is still open," Lieutenant-Colonel Richard Hecht, chief military spokesperson to the foreign media, said in a briefing. "Anyone who can get out, I would advise them to get out." Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli military suggests Gazans fleeing strikes head to Egypt

children.content: The Israeli military has suggested that Palestinians fleeing its air strikes in the Gaza Strip head to Egypt, which also borders the blockaded enclave.
"I am aware that the Rafah crossing (on the Gaza-Egypt border) is still open," Lieutenant-Colonel Richard Hecht, chief military spokesperson to the foreign media, said in a briefing.
"Anyone who can get out, I would advise them to get out."
Reuters
Egypt borders the south of the Gaza Strip.
(ABC News)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel has retaken control of the Gaza border fence breached by Palestinian Hamas gunmen who carried out a weekend mass-incursion, the chief military spokesperson said on Tuesday. In remarks aired by Israel's Army Radio, Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said there had been no new infiltrations from Gaza since Monday. In an apparent response to rumours that gunmen used cross-border tunnels, he said the military had no such findings. He also said Israel was planting mines in the parts where the barrier was toppled. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel retakes control of Gaza fence, military spokesperson says

children.content: Israel has retaken control of the Gaza border fence breached by Palestinian Hamas gunmen who carried out a weekend mass-incursion, the chief military spokesperson said on Tuesday.
In remarks aired by Israel's Army Radio, Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said there had been no new infiltrations from Gaza since Monday.
In an apparent response to rumours that gunmen used cross-border tunnels, he said the military had no such findings.
He also said Israel was planting mines in the parts where the barrier was toppled.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations says the more than 187,000 people in Gaza who have fled their homes represents the highest number of people displaced in the territory since 2014. In a flash update posted to its website this afternoon, the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said: Over 187,518 people in Gaza are believed to have fled their homes, with UNRWA hosting 137,427 in 83 schools, some of which operated as emergency shelters. The number of IDPs (internally displaced persons) represents the highest number of people displaced since the 50-day escalation of hostilities in 2014, which was the deadliest escalation recorded in Gaza since 1967. Additionally, it is estimated that over 41,000 IDPs, whose homes have been destroyed or damaged, are hosted by relatives and neighbours. The UN says it expects the number of displaced people in the Gaza Strip to increase further.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Highest number of Gaza residents displaced since 2014, UN believes

children.content: The United Nations says the more than 187,000 people in Gaza who have fled their homes represents the highest number of people displaced in the territory since 2014.
In a flash update posted to its website this afternoon, the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said:
Over 187,518 people in Gaza are believed to have fled their homes, with UNRWA hosting 137,427 in 83 schools, some of which operated as emergency shelters.

The number of IDPs (internally displaced persons) represents the highest number of people displaced since the 50-day escalation of hostilities in 2014, which was the deadliest escalation recorded in Gaza since 1967.
Additionally, it is estimated that over 41,000 IDPs, whose homes have been destroyed or damaged, are hosted by relatives and neighbours.
The UN says it expects the number of displaced people in the Gaza Strip to increase further.

That was fast.
The Demons will get a future third round pick back. A quick and easy deal that suits everyone as the Dogs add an experienced body to their midfield.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Executive GM of football at Fremantle Peter Bell has been speaking to Trade Radio about Lachie Schultz's request to join Collingwood. He wouldn't be pressed as to what the Dockers would be asking for in return, but did leave the door open for Schultz to stay. Here's what he had to say: "Lachie advised yesterday that for a few different reasons he was interested in ammove to Vivtory and would like to play at Collingwood. We're open to listening to Collingwood, but there's a strong possibility that he'll be playing in 2024 for us. "He hit a contract trigger for an extra year on his contract to the end of 2024. We had been in discussion for a further extension for an extra couple of years. "There was an element of surprise that the request came, but we acknowledge that circumstances can change. "He's a big part of our plans and he's a valued teammate."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Peter Bell details Fremantle's Lachie Schultz position

children.content: (Getty Images)

Executive GM of football at Fremantle Peter Bell has been speaking to Trade Radio about Lachie Schultz's request to join Collingwood. He wouldn't be pressed as to what the Dockers would be asking for in return, but did leave the door open for Schultz to stay.
Here's what he had to say:
"Lachie advised yesterday that for a few different reasons he was interested in ammove to Vivtory and would like to play at Collingwood.
We're open to listening to Collingwood, but there's a strong possibility that he'll be playing in 2024 for us.
"He hit a contract trigger for an extra year on his contract to the end of 2024. We had been in discussion for a further extension for an extra couple of years.
"There was an element of surprise that the request came, but we acknowledge that circumstances can change.
"He's a big part of our plans and he's a valued teammate."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Next up in our look at the top draft prospects of 2023 is Colby McKercher, our Tasmanian midfield dynamo. As a pure midfielder, there is no better option in this year's draft. McKercher is a prolific ball winner both inside the contest and as an outside receiver, and has uses it well with his tidy left foot. But where McKercher really stands out is his speed and agility. Combine that with his willingness to take defenders on and find creative solutions on the field and you're looking at a midfielder with real hurt factor. Think of a Errol Gulden or Connor Rozee type, the sort of player that can impact at the stoppage but push forward for a goal or two a game. McKercher is fun to watch, because he'll very rarely take the boring and safe option. There has been some talk that teams might be a little put off by the Tasmania of it all, but McKercher has been at pains all year to stress he is keen to head to the mainland and is determined to be a one-club player wherever he ends up. McKercher is a top-three prospect and there is no way he'll slip out of the top five.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Colby McKercher

children.content: (Getty Images)
Next up in our look at the top draft prospects of 2023 is Colby McKercher, our Tasmanian midfield dynamo.

As a pure midfielder, there is no better option in this year's draft. McKercher is a prolific ball winner both inside the contest and as an outside receiver, and has uses it well with his tidy left foot.

But where McKercher really stands out is his speed and agility. Combine that with his willingness to take defenders on and find creative solutions on the field and you're looking at a midfielder with real hurt factor.

Think of a Errol Gulden or Connor Rozee type, the sort of player that can impact at the stoppage but push forward for a goal or two a game. McKercher is fun to watch, because he'll very rarely take the boring and safe option.
(Getty Images)

There has been some talk that teams might be a little put off by the Tasmania of it all, but McKercher has been at pains all year to stress he is keen to head to the mainland and is determined to be a one-club player wherever he ends up.
McKercher is a top-three prospect and there is no way he'll slip out of the top five.

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on ABC's Afternoon Briefing, speaking from Uluru

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog as we bring you the latest news in the lead-up to voting day on October 14.

title.children: Anthony Albanese says the race is far from over ahead of Voice referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Daniel Keane According to the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC), the prepoll vote is "very large" compared to previous national polls, and numbers over 3 million. Australian Electoral Commissioner Tom Rogers told the ABC’s Afternoon Briefings that the figure was partly a reflection of the fact that there are more enrolled voters than ever before. "We're nudging up towards about a third of the electorate [who] have already cast a vote or applied for a vote," he told the ABC's Greg Jennett. "I just checked a couple of minutes ago — 3.3 million Australians have already had a pre-poll vote. About 2.1 million Australians have applied for a postal vote, many of those are now on their way." Rogers said the AEC's mobile teams had collected about 100,000 votes, including in remote communities, and that 20,000 votes had been cast overseas, including 7,000 at the High Commission in London.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 3.3 million Australians have already pre-polled, AEC says

children.content: Reporting by Daniel Keane
According to the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC), the prepoll vote is "very large" compared to previous national polls, and numbers
over 3 million

props.alt: Tom speaks from a polling station.

children.content: (ABC News)
Australian Electoral Commissioner
Tom Rogers
told the ABC’s Afternoon Briefings that the figure was partly a reflection of the fact that there are more enrolled voters than ever before.
"We're nudging up towards about a third of the electorate [who] have already cast a vote or applied for a vote," he told the ABC's
Greg Jennett
"I just checked a couple of minutes ago — 3.3 million Australians have already had a pre-poll vote. About 2.1 million Australians have applied for a postal vote, many of those are now on their way."
Rogers said the AEC's mobile teams had collected about 100,000 votes, including in remote communities, and that 20,000 votes had been cast overseas, including 7,000 at the High Commission in London.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Turning now to campaign practices and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been asked on Afternoon Briefing if the government will order a review of laws that govern these processes. "At the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, they will normally look at electoral processes when they occur at the federal level. That will be a matter for the committee," Albanese told the ABC. "What I'm focused on is the outcome on Saturday, and then I will focus on getting it done, getting the Voice put in place and it will be a very positive uplifting moment. " I see this as being just like the apology to the Stolen Generation. There was a lot of concern, and, frankly, fake news about what the consequences of it would be. There would be all these negative consequences. None of them were realised. "We know that it was an uplifting moment, particularly, I think, for young Australians at that time. Every school in the whole country stopped to hear the apology. "Brendan Nelson gave a fine speech as Liberal leader. It is unfortunate that Peter Dutton walked out on that speech. He found the consequences he was talking about, though, weren't realised. He has apologised for that but is committing exactly the same actions in being negative, saying No on this."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM compares misinformation about Voice to 'fake news' around apology to Stolen Generation

props.alt: Albanese stands in front of Ayres Rock in Uluru.

children.content: (ABC News)
Turning now to campaign practices and Prime Minister
Anthony Albanese
has been asked on
Afternoon Briefing
if the government will order a review of laws that govern these processes.

"At the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, they will normally look at electoral processes when they occur at the federal level. That will be a matter for the committee," Albanese told the ABC.
"What I'm focused on is the outcome on Saturday, and then I will focus on getting it done, getting the Voice put in place and it will be a very positive uplifting moment.
I see this as being just like the apology to the Stolen Generation. There was a lot of concern, and, frankly, fake news about what the consequences of it would be.
There would be all these negative consequences. None of them were realised.
"We know that it was an uplifting moment, particularly, I think, for young Australians at that time. Every school in the whole country stopped to hear the apology.

"Brendan Nelson gave a fine speech as Liberal leader. It is unfortunate that Peter Dutton walked out on that speech. He found the consequences he was talking about, though, weren't realised. He has apologised for that but
is committing exactly the same actions
in being negative, saying No on this."

items.synopsis: Australia's share market is up after Wall Street's major indexes closed higher overnight.

title.children: Virgin Australia posts profit, ASX gains ground, Origin Energy shares surge after regulator approves takeover

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The banking regulator wants to give superannuation members a clearer picture of how their money is being spent and invested, under proposed new plans. APRA wants to publish total fund expenditure and expanded asset allocation data by mid next year. Deputy Chair Margaret Cole says the proposals represent an important step forward in achieving greater transparency in superannuation. "It is APRA's aim to publish as much of the data that we collect as possible, especially where there is a strong public interest in having access to high quality industry data that is comparable across funds," she said. "Under these proposals, members would have a clearer and more detailed picture of how their money is being spent and invested, while trustees would be further compelled to remain closely focused on improving member outcomes." It has invited super trustees and other industry stakeholders to provide feedback on its plans by the end of November.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Super funds to detail spending under APRA proposal

children.content: The banking regulator wants to give superannuation members a clearer picture of how their money is being spent and invested, under proposed new plans.
APRA wants to publish total fund expenditure and expanded asset allocation data by mid next year.
Deputy Chair Margaret Cole says the proposals represent an important step forward in achieving greater transparency in superannuation.

"It is APRA's aim to publish as much of the data that we collect as possible, especially where there is a strong public interest in having access to high quality industry data that is comparable across funds," she said.

"Under these proposals, members would have a clearer and more detailed picture of how their money is being spent and invested, while trustees would be further compelled to remain closely focused on improving member outcomes."
It has invited super trustees and other industry stakeholders to provide feedback on its plans by the end of November.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Energy giant Chevron says talks with unions are progressing, despite the threat of fresh strikes next week. The company has asked Australia's industrial tribunal to help resolve a 'small number' of issues blocking a deal with unions at its two natural gas facilities in Western Australia. These include details about how travel and meal expenses are reimbursed and cabin sharing on the offshore platform. Chevron says once it receives clarification from the Fair Work Commission, it will be able to finalise the Enterprise Agreements for employees to vote on. The union has given the company notice about plans for protected industrial action including work stoppages and partial work bans starting on 19 October. "While we don't believe that industrial action is necessary, given we are seeking the assistance of the Fair Work Commission to resolve the small number of outstanding items between the parties, we will continue to take steps to maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption to our facilities," said a Chevron Australia spokesperson.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron says deal with unions possible

children.content: Energy giant Chevron says talks with unions are progressing, despite the threat of fresh strikes next week.
The company has asked
Australia's industrial tribunal to help resolve a 'small number' of issues blocking a deal with unions
at its two natural gas facilities in Western Australia.
These include details about
how travel and meal expenses are reimbursed and cabin sharing
on the offshore platform.
Chevron says once it receives clarification from the Fair Work Commission, it will be able to
finalise the Enterprise Agreements
for employees to vote on.
The union has given the company notice about plans for protected industrial action including
work stoppages and partial work bans starting on 19 October

"While we don't believe that industrial action is necessary, given we are seeking the assistance of the Fair Work Commission to resolve the small number of outstanding items between the parties, we will continue to take steps to maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption to our facilities," said a Chevron Australia spokesperson.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Virgin Australia has reported a statutory net profit after tax of $129 million for the full year, its first profit in 11 years. It compares to a loss of $565.5 million in 2022. Revenue more than doubled to $5 billion, after a strong increase in customer demand for travel, despite cost of living pressure. CEO Jayne Hrdlicka says it is 'an important milestone' for the airline. "By creating a systemically lower cost base and a conservative balance sheet as well as investing heavily in technology and our frontline, we are well positioned for the future," she said. Virgin Australia was purchased in 2020 for $3.5 billion by US private equity firm Bain Capital, after the airline was placed into voluntary administration. "Our balance sheet is now considerably stronger and the cost base of the business has significantly improved from recent years," said Virgin's CFO Race Strauss. Earlier this year Bain Capital confirmed it is looking to relist Virgin Australia on the Australian Securities Exchange at some stage.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Virgin Australia posts first profit in more than a decade

at some stage.
